prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 3: NGC4472 & NGC4636
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
We propose to observe the nearby ellipticals NGC4472 and NGC4636, to search for excess mm-wave emission at 96.7 GHz that is postulated to arise from synchrotron self-absorbed electrons in an Advection Dominated Accretion Flow (ADAF). These targets have low cm-wave radio powers, low and well-constrained dust emission and host radiatively inefficient AGN, making them ideal targets from which to directly detect SMBH ADAF emission.
Our Band 3 & 4 observations are highly flexible and can be performed in very poor weather conditions. However, our science goals require that both bands be taken as near to simultaneously as possible in order that the measured spectral indices are not affected by any potential fast variability.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: This is essentially a straightforward detection experiment, hence we have requested the standard continuum mode set-up for band 3. The use of all four sub-bands ensures the maximum possible sensitivity.

We require the high angular resolution of ALMA to isolate, as far as is practically possible, the nuclear point source. Our request for 0.45 arcsec resolution is chosen to correspond to the Bondi radius (~50-100pc) for these sources, allowing us to isolate the emission from within here. Assuming ADAF emission, our actual physical region of interest for the nuclear component is only a few tens of Schwarzchild radii, hence impossible even with ALMA in its most extended resolution. Higher resolution observations would therefore offer minimal gain. Differentiating ADAF candidate emission from potential extended emission is crucial for our goals. Jets and/or dust are expected to be extended on scales greater than the Bondi radius, hence we will produce maps of our recovered flux at varying levels of uv-tapering. This will enable us to check that any emission we recover is truly unresolved, at levels even below our already deep detection limit for extended structure.
We do not expect any significant extended structure within our field of view. However, as stated, precise excision of any confusing extended sources is paramount. We have chosen 5.0 arcsec as the maximum recoverable angular scale as a compromise between being sensitive to as many potential contaminant scales as possible, whilst being the maximum extent to which overheads do not increase in the Time Calculator due to a requirement for multiple configurations.

The full bandwidth is required to achieve the highest possible continuum sensitivity in the shortest integration time. Our science goals require ALMA for its unrivaled spatial resolution. We do not expect to be sensitivity limited. We predict an ADAF luminosity of 5x10^20 W/Hz at ~97 GHz using the scaling relations of Mahadevan 1997, assuming typical viscosity parameters and a black hole mass 1x10^9 solar masses accreting at a rate of ~3x10^-4 Eddington, which are expected values for radiatively inefficient AGN in elliptical galaxies of this size. This luminosity translates to predicted fluxes of 15.0 & 19.4 mJy at 97.5 GHz for NGC4472 & NGC4636 respectively. A 5 sigma detection of this nuclear source can be achieved in significantly less than a second on-source, which is impractically short. A 1-minute on source integration is as short as practically possible, achieving a SNR > 150 for the expected nuclear continuum, ensuring that high significance detections are possible for even the worst weather conditions. Such a low detection limit ensures that in the case of non-detections we will be placing highly stringent constraints on ADAF models for these objects, essentially disproving many predictions. An additional benefit of this extremely high sensitivity is that we will be able to directly detect the presence of any weak, extended dust and/or jet emission. Differentiating between true ADAF emission and jets is a significant complication, hence these limits will greatly restrict the origin of any flux we recover.
These targets are close enough (<10 degrees) together on the sky that they can be observed in a single block, which minimises overheads.

We require the high angular resolution of ALMA to isolate, as far as is practically possible, the nuclear point source. Our request for 0.45 arcsec resolution is chosen to correspond to the Bondi radius (~50-100pc) for these sources, allowing us to isolate the emission from within here. Assuming ADAF emission, our actual physical region of interest for the nuclear component is only a few tens of Schwarzchild radii, hence impossible even with ALMA in its most extended resolution. Higher resolution observations would therefore offer minimal gain. Differentiating ADAF candidate emission from potential extended emission is crucial for our goals. Jets and/or dust are expected to be extended on scales greater than the Bondi radius, hence we will produce maps of our recovered flux at varying levels of uv-tapering. This will enable us to check that any emission we recover is truly unresolved, at levels even below our already deep detection limit for extended structure.
We do not expect any significant extended structure within our field of view. However, as stated, precise excision of any confusing extended sources is paramount. We have chosen 5.0 arcsec as the maximum recoverable angular scale as a compromise between being sensitive to as many potential contaminant scales as possible, whilst being the maximum extent to which overheads do not increase in the Time Calculator due to a requirement for multiple configurations.

The full bandwidth is required to achieve the highest possible continuum sensitivity in the shortest integration time. Our science goals require ALMA for its unrivaled spatial resolution. We do not expect to be sensitivity limited. We predict an ADAF luminosity of 1x10^21 W/Hz at ~145 GHz using the scaling relations of Mahadevan 1997, assuming typical viscosity parameters and a black hole mass 1x10^9 solar masses accreting at a rate of ~3x10^-4 Eddington, which are expected values for radiatively inefficient AGN in elliptical galaxies of this size. This luminosity translates to a predicted flux of 9.5 mJy at 145.7 GHz for NGC7049. A 5 sigma detection of this nuclear source can be achieved in significantly less than a second on-source, which is impractically short. A 1-minute on source integration is as short as practically possible, achieving a SNR > 95 for the expected nuclear continuum, ensuring that high significance detections are possible for even the worst weather conditions. Such a low detection limit ensures that in the case of non-detections we will be placing highly stringent constraints on ADAF models for these objects, essentially disproving many predictions. An additional benefit of this extremely high sensitivity is that we will be able to directly detect the presence of any weak, extended dust and/or jet emission. Differentiating between true ADAF emission and jets is a significant complication, hence these limits will greatly restrict the origin of any flux we recover.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The central engines in "mechanical mode" AGN are powered by radiatively inefficient Advection Dominated Accretion Flows (ADAFs). However, emission expected to be directly associated with an ADAF around a super-massive black hole has only thus far been detected in Sgr A* and the recently discovered strong ADAF candidate in NGC5044. Here we propose poor-weather observations in bands 3 & 4 of a sample of 7 nearby ellipticals that have weak cm-wave radio powers and low, well-constrained dust emission. They all host radiatively inefficient AGN, and are hence strong ADAF candidate systems in which to observe the (sub-)mm bump that is postulated to arise due to hot synchrotron self-absorbed electrons in the accretion flow itself.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: Intensive monitoring of the core of NGC5044 - An Advection Dominated Accretion Flow in Action? (P.I. Alastair Edge)
